results.title: Streams of our city
results.creator_credit: Filmpartnership and Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works
results.brief_description: For the people and industry of Melbourne, the rivers and streams of the city are as important today as they were to the first settlers. However little thought was given to their character and natural purpose as draining systems. Neglect has inevitably led to deterioration. This film shows some of the problems and ways of overcoming them.

results.title: Streamlines
results.creator_credit: BBC, Time Inc and James Kent
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “American visions”.
This episode covers American art and architecture from the Wall Street Crash to the eve of the Second World War. Even as Manhattan was on the verge of the Depression, the skyscraper reigned supreme. “New York’s shifting, rising skyline was like nothing Europe had ever seen”, notes Hughes, as he outlines Art Deco and describes the construction of the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building. FDR’s New Deal employed artists through the WPA (Works Progress Administration), which itself was the center of controversy when Diego Rivera had his left-wing fresco painted over by capitalist tycoon John D. Rockefeller. Major projects such as the Hoover Dam, representing “a rallying symbol for American self-confidence, so bruised and battered by the Great Depression,” were constructed. Urban artists such as Jacob Lawrence, Edward Hopper and Stuart Davis are featured. In the American Midwest, artists evoked a more conservative perspective, depicting idyllic scenes of rural and farm life. Highly innovative design was used to sell consumers a modern lifestyle. This movement culminated with the exhibition dedicated to the modern machine, the New York World’s Fair of 1939, which is remembered today as the last burst of utopian belief in the machine before the destruction left by the military technology of World War II. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Streamers
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions, Streamers International, Nick Mileti and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Set in an Army barracks in 1965, a group of young soldiers wait assignment to Vietnam. The draftees come from diverse backgrounds: two are afro-americans, one a country boy and the other a Yale-educated homosexual. They are confronted by two brutal ex-Korean war veteran sergeants. Sexual and racial tensions build as the men wait in their claustrophobic barracks but eventually shocking violence erupts. The barracks is a microcosm of the explosive emotions and issues which surfaced in America at that time, however the theatrical nature of the original material, (based on a play by David Rabe) is reflected in a static production which is more stagebound than fluid. The performances, especially by Matthew Modine, Michael Wright and George Dzundza are superb.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rank Film Productions, Streamers International, Nick Mileti and Robert Altman

results.creator_credit: Crawley Films, International Film Bureau and Kenneth Campbell
results.brief_description: Examines through seasonal changes and by following the course of a flowing water system, the two basic types of stream environments - erosional and depositional habits.

results.title: Stray dog = Nora Inu
results.creator_credit: Shintoho, Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Shojiro Motoki and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: A young detective Murakami (Toshiro Mifune) has his police gun pick-pocketed on a packed bus in Tokyo. Fearing dismissal, Murakami trawls Tokyo’s underbelly encountering a slew of criminals, black market gunrunners and sleazy types in his quest to recover his weapon and halt the murders occurring at the hand of the thief. In Kurosawa’s ninth feature, the pace is languorous, reflecting the oppressive heat of Occupied Tokyo, sapping the resistance of the many characters that pepper the narrative, sweating their way through an excessive heatwave, battling poverty whilst living amid slums and atrocious post-war conditions. Kurosawa presents a fine example of a noir detective movie, exhibiting his technical virtuosity in a series of vignettes as Murakami chases thieves through grimy back alleys, and sleazy dancehalls, as his naivete ebbs away. Gloomy, intense and atmospheric, this film, about an obsessive quest, delineates a loss of innocence for a rookie cop in search of truth where poverty and degradation causes desperation and amorality to thrive in an urban setting. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Strawberry and chocolate = fresa y chocolate
results.creator_credit: Cuban Institute of Arts and Film Industry, Imcine, Tabasco Films, Miguel Mendoza, Tomas Gutierrez Alea and Juan Carlos Tabio
results.brief_description: A young Cuban Communist Party cadre is shocked to find himself pursued by a witty, handsome homosexual. By exploring the friendship that develops between a straight man and a gay man in a culture which forbids open expression of homosexuality, “Strawberry and Chocolate” manages to raise important political questions while remaining delightfully comic throughout. The film exposes Cuba’s anti-gay laws by showing the important role gay and lesbian revolutionaries, writers and artists played in Cuban culture and examines how political censorship in any context only impoverishes a society. Jorge Perugorria and Vladimir Cruz are excellent as the two friends and Mirta Ibarra steals every scene she is in as a vivacious and sexy Cuban woman who refuses to allow Latin machismo to dictate her life and choices.

results.title: Strawberries without cream
results.brief_description: Strawberry plants are subject to virus degeneration diseases which formerly restricted the industry in Victoria. Resistant strains are now bred in an isolated area and supplied to growers, all plantings being replaced every three years, and the problem is controlled. The film shows how the scheme operates.

results.title: Straw dogs (D)
results.creator_credit: ABC Pictures (US), Daniel Melnick and Sam Peckinpah
results.brief_description: This violent story of rape and retribution is a masterpiece of thriller film-making, though argument still rages over Peckinpah’s confused mixture of primitive machismo and contemptuous elitism. David (Dustin Hoffman), a young American professor, moves into an isolated Cornish farmhouse with his English wife, Amy (Susan George). Their retreat is disturbed by the harrasment of workmen who are repairing the farmhouse. These brutal and stupid locals alternatively taunt the Professor and are lewdly suggestive with a willing Amy. It is not until Amy is savagely raped, and a local mentally handicapped man (David Warner) is also attacked by the mob, that David’s repressed anger is unleashed and he takes his murderous revenge on the “hick” locals. Peckinpah is arguably the most operatic of American directors and his theme of the lone individual male exacting punishment when society fails its victims was to influence films as diverse as “Death Wish” and the Dirty Harry trilogy. Pauline Kael called “Straw Dogs” “a fascist work of art”. The film still unsettles and disturbs: it’s misogyny is hateful, it’s resolution undeniably exhilerating.

results.title: Stravinsky
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Roman Kroitor and Wolf Koenig
results.brief_description: An informal study of the great but extremely human dean of modern composers, a man past eighty, (at the time of making this film) full of the joy of life and, though proudly American, still very much an Old World figure with a long and alert memory for people and events in music, literature and art. The main focus of the film is Igor Stravinsky conducting the CBC Symphony Orchestra in a recording of his Symphony of Psalms.

results.title: Stratford on Avon
results.brief_description: Offers a colorful display of Tudor buildings and gardens. Ann Hathaway’s famous cottage, and Shakespeare’s birth-place, exemplify Tudor half-timbered architecture. Shows lively scenes such as the annual Mop Fair.
results.description: Offers a colorful display of Tudor buildings and gardens. Ann Hathaway’s famous cottage, and Shakespeare’s birth-place, exemplify Tudor half-timbered architecture. Shows lively scenes such as the annual Mop Fair.
